meta.title: Computer Science MCQs
meta.description: Practice questions on History and Generation of Computers.
meta.keywords: computer science, history, generations, vacuum tubes, transistors

questions.q: Which generation of computers used vacuum tubes?
questions.ex: First-generation computers (1940s–1950s) used vacuum tubes for processing.

questions.q: What technology replaced vacuum tubes in the second generation?
questions.ex: Transistors (1950s–1960s) were smaller, faster, and more energy-efficient.

questions.q: ENIAC was primarily designed for:
questions.ex: ENIAC (1945) was built to calculate artillery trajectories for the U.S. Army.

questions.q: Which generation introduced integrated circuits (ICs)?
questions.ex: Third-generation computers (1960s–1970s) used ICs, enabling smaller and faster systems.

questions.q: UNIVAC was an example of:
questions.ex: UNIVAC (1951) was a first-gen computer using vacuum tubes.

questions.q: The microprocessor was introduced in which generation?
questions.ex: Fourth-gen (1970s–present) uses microprocessors (VLSI technology).

questions.q: What was the main limitation of vacuum tubes?
questions.ex: Vacuum tubes were bulky, consumed high power, and generated excessive heat.

questions.q: Which early computer used punched cards for input?
questions.ex: Harvard Mark I (1944) used punched paper tape for programming.

questions.q: The term 'bug' in computing originated from:
options: A moth in Harvard Mark II
questions.ex: A moth caused a hardware fault in Harvard Mark II (1947), coined as the first 'debugging'.

questions.q: Which generation introduced high-level programming languages like COBOL?
questions.ex: Second-gen (1950s–1960s) saw languages like COBOL and FORTRAN.

questions.q: EDSAC was developed in:
questions.ex: EDSAC (1949) was the first practical stored-program computer, built in the UK.

questions.q: The IBM 360 series belonged to which generation?
questions.ex: IBM 360 (1964) was a third-gen system using ICs.

questions.q: What characterized fifth-generation computers?
questions.ex: Fifth-gen (1980s–present) focuses on AI, ULSI, and quantum computing.

questions.q: Who is considered the 'father of the computer'?
questions.ex: Babbage designed the Analytical Engine (1837), a precursor to modern computers.

questions.q: The von Neumann architecture is based on:
questions.ex: Von Neumann's design (1945) stored both data and instructions in memory.

questions.q: Which first-gen computer was binary-based?
questions.ex: Konrad Zuse's Z3 (1941) was the first binary programmable computer.

questions.q: The first electronic general-purpose computer was:
questions.ex: ENIAC (1945) was the first Turing-complete electronic computer.

questions.q: What was the primary storage in first-gen computers?
questions.ex: Punched cards and paper tape were used for input/output and storage.

questions.q: Which company dominated the second-gen computer market?
questions.ex: IBM's 7000 series (e.g., 7090) were iconic second-gen systems.

questions.q: The Apple I (1976) belonged to which generation?
questions.ex: Apple I used a microprocessor (MOS 6502), making it fourth-gen.

questions.q: What innovation defined third-gen computers?
questions.ex: Third-gen introduced OSes (e.g., UNIX) and time-sharing for multitasking.

questions.q: Which early computer was used for code-breaking in WWII?
questions.ex: Colossus (1943) decrypted German messages at Bletchley Park.

questions.q: The Cray-1 supercomputer was:
questions.ex: Cray-1 (1976) was a fourth-gen vector-processing supercomputer.

questions.q: What replaced magnetic core memory in fourth-gen computers?
questions.ex: Semiconductor RAM (DRAM/SRAM) became standard in the 1970s.

questions.q: Which generation saw the rise of personal computers?
questions.ex: Fourth-gen (1970s–1980s) brought PCs like Apple II and IBM PC.

questions.q: Which type of computer is designed for a single user?
questions.ex: Personal Computers (PCs) are designed for individual use.

questions.q: What is the primary purpose of a supercomputer?
questions.ex: Supercomputers are used for complex calculations in scientific and engineering fields.

questions.q: Which of these is an example of a mainframe computer?
questions.ex: IBM zSeries are powerful mainframes used for critical enterprise applications.

questions.q: Embedded computers are commonly found in:
questions.ex: Embedded systems are specialized computers built into larger systems like ATMs or traffic lights.

questions.q: What distinguishes a workstation from a regular PC?
questions.ex: Workstations offer superior performance for specialized tasks like 3D rendering.

questions.q: Which type of computer is designed to provide services to other computers?
questions.ex: Servers provide shared resources or services to client computers.

questions.q: Quantum computers differ from classical computers by using:
questions.ex: Quantum computers use quantum bits (qubits) that can exist in superposition states.

questions.q: Which computer type would be most suitable for weather forecasting?
questions.ex: Supercomputers can process massive datasets required for weather modeling.

questions.q: What is a characteristic of a minicomputer?
options: Fits in the palm of your hand
questions.ex: Minicomputers are mid-sized systems between mainframes and microcomputers.

questions.q: Which of these is NOT a portable computer?
questions.ex: Mainframes are large, non-portable systems designed for enterprise use.

questions.q: What type of computer would a bank most likely use for transaction processing?
questions.ex: Mainframes handle high-volume transaction processing for banks.

questions.q: Which computer type is designed to be worn on the body?
questions.ex: Wearable computers like smartwatches are designed for personal use on the body.

questions.q: What is the primary advantage of a thin client?
questions.ex: Thin clients rely on servers for processing, reducing local hardware requirements.

questions.q: Which type of computer is most suitable for airline reservation systems?
questions.ex: Mainframes handle large-scale, real-time transaction systems like airline reservations.

questions.q: What distinguishes a microcomputer from other types?
questions.ex: Microcomputers are built around a single microprocessor chip.

questions.q: Which computer type would be used for controlling traffic lights?
questions.ex: Embedded systems are specialized for control applications like traffic management.

questions.q: What is a characteristic of a server computer?
questions.ex: Servers are built for high reliability and continuous operation.

questions.q: Which of these is an example of a handheld computer?
questions.ex: PDAs (Personal Digital Assistants) are early examples of handheld computers.

questions.q: What type of computer is specifically designed for playing video games?
questions.ex: Game consoles are optimized for gaming performance and experience.

questions.q: Which computer type is most likely to use a RISC processor?
questions.ex: Embedded systems often use RISC processors for efficiency.

questions.q: What is the primary use of a blade server?
questions.ex: Blade servers are compact systems designed for data center deployment.

questions.q: Which type of computer would be used for computer-aided design (CAD)?
questions.ex: Workstations provide the power needed for CAD applications.

questions.q: What distinguishes a tablet computer from a laptop?
questions.ex: Tablets primarily use touchscreen interfaces rather than keyboards/mice.

questions.q: Which computer type is most energy efficient?
questions.ex: Embedded systems are optimized for low power consumption.

questions.q: What is a common feature of all modern personal computers?
questions.ex: All modern PCs are built around microprocessor technology.

questions.q: What is the decimal equivalent of binary 1010?
questions.ex: 1010 in binary is 1×2³ + 0×2² + 1×2¹ + 0×2⁰ = 8 + 0 + 2 + 0 = 10 in decimal.

questions.q: The hexadecimal number 'F' represents decimal:
questions.ex: In hexadecimal, A=10, B=11, ..., F=15.

questions.q: Which number system has a base of 8?
questions.ex: Octal system uses base-8 (digits 0-7).

questions.q: What is the binary equivalent of decimal 15?
questions.ex: 15 in decimal is 8 + 4 + 2 + 1 = 1111 in binary.

questions.q: How many bits are needed to represent decimal 32?
questions.ex: 2⁵ = 32, so 5 bits are needed (100000 in binary).

questions.q: The octal number 17 represents decimal:
questions.ex: Octal 17 = 1×8¹ + 7×8⁰ = 8 + 7 = 15 in decimal.

questions.q: Which of these is NOT a valid hexadecimal digit?
questions.ex: Hexadecimal uses 0-9 and A-F (where G is invalid).

questions.q: What is 1101 in binary minus 101 in binary?
The two's complement representation is used for:
questions.ex: Two's complement is a method to represent signed (positive/negative) numbers.

questions.q: What is the hexadecimal equivalent of binary 11001100?
questions.ex: 11001100 = CC in hex (split as 1100=C and 1100=C).

questions.q: Which number system is most commonly used in digital circuits?
questions.ex: Binary (base-2) directly represents on/off states in electronics.

questions.q: The BCD (Binary Coded Decimal) representation of decimal 9 is:
questions.ex: BCD encodes each decimal digit separately (9 = 1001).

questions.q: What is the result of binary 101 AND 011?
The largest 4-bit binary number is:
questions.ex: 1111 in binary equals 15 in decimal (the maximum 4-bit value).

questions.q: What is the octal equivalent of hexadecimal 'A'?
questions.ex: Hex A (decimal 10) = Octal 12 (1×8¹ + 2×8⁰).

questions.q: Which operation is used to convert decimal to binary?
questions.ex: Repeated division-by-2 with remainders gives binary digits.

questions.q: The binary number 10101.101 equals decimal:
What is the hexadecimal result of 7 + 9?
questions.ex: 7 + 9 = 16 in decimal, which is '10' in hexadecimal.

questions.q: Which is the correct binary fraction for decimal 0.75?
The Gray code is used primarily for:
questions.ex: Gray code ensures only one bit changes between adjacent numbers.

questions.q: What is the 8-bit two's complement representation of -5?
The binary subtraction 1010 - 0101 equals:
Which number system uses digits 0-7?
questions.ex: Octal is base-8 (digits 0-7).

questions.q: The hexadecimal number '1A3' equals decimal:
What is the binary equivalent of octal 45?
Which of these represents an even number in binary?
questions.ex: Even numbers end with 0 in binary (1010 = 10 in decimal).

questions.q: The 1's complement of binary 1100 is:
questions.ex: 1's complement flips all bits (1100 → 0011).

questions.q: What is the result of binary 110 XOR 101?
The hexadecimal system is often used in computing because:
options: It's easier for humans than octal
questions.ex: Hex (base-16) concisely represents binary (1 hex digit = 4 binary digits).

questions.q: What is the decimal value of the binary floating-point 1.1×2³?
questions.ex: 1.1 in binary = 1.5 in decimal. 1.5 × 2³ = 12.

questions.q: Which logic gate outputs 1 only when all inputs are 1?
questions.ex: AND gate follows the rule: 1 AND 1 = 1; all other combinations = 0.

questions.q: The Boolean expression for a NOT gate with input A is:
questions.ex: NOT gate inverts the input (Ā represents NOT A).

questions.q: What is the output of an XOR gate when both inputs are 1?
questions.ex: XOR outputs 1 only when inputs differ (1 XOR 1 = 0).

questions.q: Which gate is called the 'universal gate'?
questions.ex: NAND (and NOR) gates can construct all other gates.

questions.q: The Boolean expression A + A.B simplifies to:
questions.ex: By Absorption Law: A + A.B = A(1 + B) = A.

questions.q: Which gate implements the logical OR operation?
questions.ex: OR gate outputs 1 if any input is 1.

questions.q: The complement of A.B (A AND B) is:
questions.ex: De Morgan's Law: Complement of A.B = Ā + B̄.

questions.q: A NOR gate is equivalent to:
questions.ex: NOR = NOT OR (OR gate output inverted).

questions.q: The Boolean expression for a 2-input NAND gate is:
questions.ex: NAND = NOT AND (A · B is inverted).

questions.q: Which law states A + Ā = 1?
questions.ex: Complement Law: A variable OR its complement always equals 1.

questions.q: The number of possible inputs for a 3-input AND gate is:
questions.ex: 2³ = 8 possible combinations (000 to 111).

questions.q:
Which gate is this truth table representing?
Inputs: 00=1, 01=1, 10=1, 11=0
questions.ex: NAND outputs 0 only when all inputs are 1.

questions.q: The dual of the Boolean expression A + B = B + A is:
questions.ex: Dual swaps '+' with '.' and 1s with 0s (commutativity holds for both).

questions.q: Which gate is used to implement binary addition?
questions.ex: XOR computes sum, AND computes carry in half-adders.

questions.q: The Boolean expression A + Ā.B simplifies to:
Which of these is NOT a valid Boolean algebra law?
questions.ex: OR (+) and AND (·) are not equivalent operations.

questions.q: A 2-input XOR gate can be built using:
questions.ex: XOR = ((A NAND (A NAND B)) NAND ((B NAND (A NAND B))).

questions.q: The output of an OR gate with inputs A=0 and B=1 is:
questions.ex: OR outputs 1 if any input is 1 (0 OR 1 = 1).

questions.q: Which theorem converts between sum-of-products and product-of-sums?
questions.ex: De Morgan's Theorem: (A+B)' = A'·B' and (A·B)' = A' + B'.

questions.q: The Boolean expression (A + B)(A + C) simplifies to:
questions.ex: By Distributive Law: (A+B)(A+C) = A + B.C.

questions.q: Which logic family is known for low power consumption?
questions.ex: CMOS (Complementary Metal-Oxide-Semiconductor) is power-efficient.

questions.q: The Boolean expression A ⊕ A is always:
questions.ex: XOR of a variable with itself is 0 (A ⊕ A = 0).

questions.q: Which gate is used to detect odd parity?
questions.ex: XOR outputs 1 for odd numbers of 1s (odd parity).

questions.q: The Boolean expression A + A.B̄ simplifies to:
questions.ex: A + A.B̄ = A(1 + B̄) = A (since 1 + B̄ = 1).

questions.q: Which IC number represents a quad 2-input AND gate?
questions.ex: 7408 is a quad 2-input AND gate IC.

questions.q: The Boolean expression (A + B)' is equivalent to:
questions.ex: De Morgan's Law: (A + B)' = A' · B'.

questions.q: Which logic gate has an output that is the complement of an AND gate?
questions.ex: NAND = NOT AND.

questions.q: The Boolean expression A.B + A.B̄ simplifies to:
Which gate is used to construct a half-adder?
questions.ex: Half-adder: XOR for sum, AND for carry.

questions.q: The Boolean expression A + (A · B) simplifies to:
questions.ex: A + (A · B) = A by Absorption Law.

questions.q: Which component is considered the 'brain' of the computer?
questions.ex: The Central Processing Unit (CPU) executes instructions and performs calculations.

questions.q: What does ALU stand for in the context of CPU?
questions.ex: The ALU performs arithmetic and logical operations within the CPU.

questions.q: The control unit (CU) is responsible for:
options: Directing and coordinating operations of the CPU
questions.ex: The CU fetches, decodes, executes, and stores results of instructions.

questions.q: Which component connects all parts of the computer and allows them to communicate?
questions.ex: The motherboard serves as the central communication backbone.

questions.q: What is the primary function of the CPU's registers?
options: Temporary storage for data being processed by the CPU
questions.ex: Registers are small, high-speed storage locations within the CPU used for immediate access to data.

questions.q: The concept of a 'stored program' computer architecture is often attributed to:
questions.ex: The von Neumann architecture defines computers that store both program instructions and data in the same memory.

questions.q: Which bus carries the addresses of data or instructions?
questions.ex: The address bus specifies the location in memory that the CPU wants to access.

questions.q: Which bus carries actual data between components?
questions.ex: The data bus carries the information being transferred (data or instructions).

questions.q: The clock speed of a CPU is typically measured in:
questions.ex: Clock speed indicates the number of cycles per second, usually in MHz or GHz.

questions.q: What is the purpose of the Fetch-Decode-Execute cycle?
options: To process instructions in the CPU
questions.ex: This is the fundamental cycle by which a CPU processes instructions.

questions.q: What is 'pipelining' in computer architecture?
options: A method for connecting multiple hard drives
A technique to allow multiple instructions to be processed concurrently
A way to cool the CPU
questions.ex: Pipelining breaks down instruction execution into stages, allowing multiple instructions to be in different stages of execution simultaneously.

questions.q: CISC (Complex Instruction Set Computer) and RISC (Reduced Instruction Set Computer) refer to different types of:
questions.ex: These are two major approaches to designing the instruction set of a CPU.

questions.q: Which of the following is NOT typically found on a motherboard?
questions.ex: An external printer is a peripheral device, not an internal component of the motherboard.

questions.q: The BIOS (Basic Input/Output System) is typically stored in:
questions.ex: BIOS is firmware stored on a ROM chip, essential for booting the computer.

questions.q: What is the purpose of the Northbridge chipset?
options: Controlling slower peripherals like hard drives
Connecting the CPU to RAM and the graphics card
questions.ex: The Northbridge (or Memory Controller Hub) handles high-speed communication between the CPU, RAM, and PCIe (graphics card).

questions.q: What is the purpose of the Southbridge chipset?
options: Controlling faster components like the CPU
Managing slower peripherals like USB, SATA, and audio
questions.ex: The Southbridge (or I/O Controller Hub) manages slower I/O functions and peripherals.

questions.q: What is 'multicore processing'?
options: A single CPU with multiple processing units (cores)
Running multiple operating systems at once
Connecting multiple monitors to a computer
questions.ex: Multicore processors contain two or more independent processing units, or 'cores', on a single chip.

questions.q: The process of starting up a computer is called:
questions.ex: Booting refers to the initial set of operations that a computer system performs when electrical power is switched on.

questions.q: What is the function of the cache memory in a computer system?
options: High-speed temporary storage for frequently accessed data
questions.ex: Cache memory acts as a buffer between the CPU and main memory to speed up data access.

questions.q: Which of the following is an example of an expansion slot on a motherboard?
questions.ex: PCIe (Peripheral Component Interconnect Express) slots are used for adding expansion cards like graphics cards, sound cards, etc.

questions.q: The instruction register (IR) in the CPU holds:
options: The address of the next instruction
questions.ex: The IR stores the instruction fetched from memory before it is decoded and executed.

questions.q: What is the role of the program counter (PC) in the CPU?
options: Points to the memory address of the next instruction to be fetched
Counts the number of programs running
questions.ex: The PC keeps track of the execution flow by holding the address of the next instruction.

questions.q: Virtual memory is a technique that:
options: Uses hard disk space as an extension of RAM
Replaces the need for RAM entirely
questions.ex: Virtual memory allows a computer to compensate for physical memory shortages by temporarily transferring data from RAM to disk storage.

questions.q: What is the primary function of a power supply unit (PSU)?
options: To convert AC power from the wall outlet to DC power for components
questions.ex: The PSU provides stable DC power at various voltages required by different computer components.

questions.q: In a von Neumann architecture, which of the following is true?
options: Instructions and data are stored in separate memories.
Instructions and data share the same memory space.
Only instructions are stored in memory.
Only data is stored in memory.
questions.ex: This is a defining characteristic of the von Neumann architecture, leading to the 'von Neumann bottleneck'.

questions.q: What is the purpose of 'overclocking' a CPU?
options: To make it run slower for better stability
To increase its clock speed beyond manufacturer's specifications
questions.ex: Overclocking aims to gain higher performance at the risk of instability and increased heat.

questions.q: What is the main role of the graphics processing unit (GPU)?
options: Handling complex mathematical calculations for general computing
questions.ex: GPUs are specialized processors optimized for parallel processing, making them ideal for graphics and parallelizable computations.

questions.q: Which type of memory is directly accessible by the CPU and used for active data and instructions?
questions.ex: RAM (Random Access Memory) is the primary working memory for the CPU.

questions.q: What is the function of a 'heat sink' in a computer?
options: To radiate heat away from components like the CPU
questions.ex: Heat sinks, often with fans, are crucial for dissipating heat generated by high-performance components.

questions.q: The concept of 'parallel processing' in computer architecture means:
options: Executing one instruction at a time very quickly.
Executing multiple instructions or parts of instructions simultaneously.
Only processing data in a sequential manner.
questions.ex: Parallel processing involves using multiple processing units or cores to perform computations concurrently.

questions.q: Which type of memory is volatile, meaning its contents are lost when the power is turned off?
questions.ex: RAM (Random Access Memory) requires power to maintain the stored information.

questions.q: What does ROM stand for?
questions.ex: ROM (Read Only Memory) is non-volatile and typically contains firmware that cannot be easily modified.

questions.q: Which memory type is the fastest and closest to the CPU?
questions.ex: Cache memory (L1, L2, L3) is extremely fast and serves as a buffer between the CPU and main memory.

questions.q: What is the primary function of RAM?
options: To store the operating system permanently
To provide long-term storage for user files
To temporarily store data and instructions that the CPU is actively using
questions.ex: RAM is the working memory of the computer, holding programs and data currently in use.

questions.q: Which type of ROM can be erased and reprogrammed using ultraviolet light?
questions.ex: EPROM (Erasable Programmable Read-Only Memory) uses UV light for erasure.

questions.q: What is the difference between SRAM and DRAM?
options: SRAM is slower and cheaper than DRAM.
DRAM is faster and more expensive than SRAM.
SRAM uses capacitors and needs refreshing, while DRAM uses latches and does not.
SRAM uses latches and does not need refreshing, while DRAM uses capacitors and needs refreshing.
questions.ex: SRAM (Static RAM) is faster and more expensive, used for cache. DRAM (Dynamic RAM) is slower, cheaper, and used for main memory.

questions.q: Which type of memory is non-volatile and can be electrically erased and reprogrammed?
questions.ex: EEPROM (Electrically Erasable Programmable Read-Only Memory) allows for electrical erasure and reprogramming.

questions.q: Flash memory is a type of:
questions.ex: Flash memory is a non-volatile computer memory that can be electrically erased and reprogrammed, commonly used in USB drives and SSDs.

questions.q: What is 'virtual memory'?
options: Using a portion of the hard drive as an extension of RAM
Memory that is physically located in the CPU
questions.ex: Virtual memory allows programs to address more memory than is physically installed, using disk space as an overflow.

questions.q: The BIOS is typically stored in which type of memory?
questions.ex: The BIOS is firmware, requiring non-volatile storage provided by ROM or Flash ROM.

questions.q: What happens when a computer runs out of physical RAM?
options: It automatically buys more RAM online.
It starts using virtual memory (swapping data to disk).
questions.ex: When physical RAM is full, the operating system uses virtual memory to swap less used data to secondary storage.

questions.q: Which memory level is the smallest but fastest, often integrated directly into the CPU?
questions.ex: L1 cache is the fastest and smallest, providing immediate access to data for the CPU.

questions.q: What is the primary advantage of SSDs (Solid State Drives) over traditional HDDs (Hard Disk Drives)?
options: Faster read/write speeds and no moving parts
questions.ex: SSDs use flash memory, providing significantly faster performance and greater durability.

questions.q: Which memory technology stores data by trapping electrons in a floating gate?
questions.ex: This is the fundamental principle behind how flash memory retains data without power.

questions.q: What does RAM's 'random access' mean?
options: Any memory location can be accessed directly in the same amount of time.
Data can only be accessed sequentially.
It can only store random numbers.
questions.ex: Unlike sequential access memory (e.g., tape drives), any byte of RAM can be accessed as quickly as any other byte.

questions.q: Which type of memory is considered main memory?
questions.ex: RAM is the primary or main memory of a computer system.

questions.q: A 'page file' or 'swap file' is associated with which memory concept?
questions.ex: These terms refer to the space on the hard drive used by the operating system for virtual memory.

questions.q: What is the function of a 'memory controller'?
options: To manage the flow of data to and from RAM
questions.ex: The memory controller is responsible for handling all requests to RAM.

questions.q: Which type of memory is typically used for firmware in embedded systems?
questions.ex: Flash memory's non-volatility and reprogrammability make it ideal for embedded system firmware.

questions.q: If a computer has 8GB of RAM, what does 'GB' stand for?
questions.ex: GB stands for Gigabytes, a unit of digital information storage.

questions.q: Why is cache memory used?
options: To reduce the speed gap between the CPU and main memory
To allow for offline data access
questions.ex: Cache memory bridges the speed difference between the very fast CPU and slower main memory.

questions.q: Which of these memory units has the fastest access time?
questions.ex: CPU registers are the fastest memory locations within the CPU itself.

questions.q: What does the term 'non-volatile' mean in relation to memory?
options: It retains its data even when power is removed.
It is only used for temporary storage.
questions.ex: Non-volatile memory persists its data without continuous power.

questions.q: Which form of memory is commonly found in USB flash drives?
questions.ex: USB drives are a prime example of devices using flash memory.

questions.q: The storage capacity of a hard disk drive (HDD) is typically measured in:
questions.ex: HDDs store large amounts of data, usually in the range of gigabytes to terabytes.

questions.q: What is 'memory interleaving'?
options: A method to encrypt memory data.
A technique to divide memory into banks that can be accessed independently.
A type of memory error correction.
A way to reduce the physical size of memory modules.
questions.ex: Memory interleaving improves performance by allowing simultaneous access to different memory banks.

questions.q: Which memory technology is used for the very small amount of fast memory on the CPU that stores instructions and data being currently processed?
questions.ex: SRAM is used for cache memory due to its speed.

questions.q: What is the purpose of a 'memory management unit' (MMU)?
options: To translate virtual addresses to physical addresses.
To provide power to memory modules.
questions.ex: The MMU is a hardware component responsible for memory address translation and protection.

questions.q: Which memory type stores data using magnetic patterns on spinning platters?
questions.ex: Hard Disk Drives (HDDs) use magnetic storage technology.

questions.q: A 'memory stick' or 'USB drive' is an example of a device using which type of memory?
questions.ex: These portable storage devices rely on flash memory.

questions.q: What is the main advantage of using DDR (Double Data Rate) RAM over older SDRAM?
options: It transfers data twice per clock cycle.
questions.ex: DDR RAM significantly increases memory bandwidth by transferring data on both the rising and falling edges of the clock signal.

questions.q: Which of the following is primarily an **input device**?
questions.ex: A keyboard allows users to enter data and commands into a computer.

questions.q: A device that converts digital information from the computer into a human-readable format is called an **output device**. Which of these fits the description?
questions.ex: A projector displays images or video onto a screen or other surface for viewing.

questions.q: Which input device uses a light-sensitive detector to select objects on a display screen?
questions.ex: A light pen is a pointing device that can detect light from a display screen, allowing direct interaction.

questions.q: Which output device produces a hard copy of text or graphics?
questions.ex: A plotter is a specialized printer used to produce high-quality, large-format graphics, such as architectural drawings.

questions.q: A device that captures images or documents and converts them into digital data is a:
questions.ex: A scanner digitizes physical documents or images.

questions.q: Which of the following is both an **input and output device**?
questions.ex: A touchscreen allows input through touch and displays output visually.

questions.q: DPI (Dots Per Inch) is a common measurement for the resolution of which device?
questions.ex: DPI indicates the resolution of a printer or scanner, representing the number of individual dots that can be placed in a line within one inch.

questions.q: Which input device is commonly used for playing video games?
questions.ex: A joystick is a common input device for controlling movement in video games.

questions.q: Optical Character Recognition (OCR) is technology primarily associated with which device?
questions.ex: OCR software works with scanners to convert images of text into actual editable text.

questions.q: Which output device generates sound?
questions.ex: Speakers convert electrical audio signals into audible sound waves.

questions.q: What is the primary function of a webcam?
options: To capture still images and video for computer input
To display images on a screen
questions.ex: A webcam is an input device used for video conferencing and capturing live video.

questions.q: Which type of printer uses toner to produce images on paper?
questions.ex: Laser printers use a laser beam to create an image on a drum, which then attracts toner particles to form the print.

questions.q: A trackball is an alternative to which input device?
questions.ex: A trackball is essentially an upside-down mouse where you move a ball with your thumb, fingers, or palm to control the cursor.

questions.q: MIDI (Musical Instrument Digital Interface) is a standard used with which input/output device?
questions.ex: MIDI allows electronic musical instruments and computers to communicate and synchronize.

questions.q: Which display technology uses organic light-emitting diodes for individual pixel illumination?
questions.ex: OLED displays offer superior contrast and true blacks as each pixel generates its own light.

questions.q: What is the main function of a graphics tablet (digitizer)?
options: To create digital drawings and sketches
questions.ex: Graphics tablets are used by artists and designers to create digital art with a stylus.

questions.q: VGA, HDMI, and DisplayPort are types of connectors for which device?
questions.ex: These are common video interfaces used to connect displays to computers.

questions.q: Which input device is typically used for biometric authentication?
questions.ex: Fingerprint scanners capture unique biometric data for user verification.

questions.q: What is the purpose of haptic feedback in input devices?
options: To provide tactile feedback (vibrations, force feedback)
questions.ex: Haptic feedback provides a sense of touch, common in game controllers and touchscreens.

questions.q: Which output device is essential for virtual reality (VR) experiences?
questions.ex: VR headsets provide immersive visual and auditory output for virtual environments.

questions.q: QR code readers are a type of which category of device?
questions.ex: QR code readers scan and interpret the information encoded in QR codes.

questions.q: The refresh rate of a monitor is measured in:
questions.ex: Refresh rate (Hz) indicates how many times per second the display updates its image.

questions.q: What is the primary function of a microphone?
options: To input audio (voice, music) into a computer
questions.ex: A microphone converts sound waves into electrical signals for digital processing.

questions.q: Which of the following is an example of an **audio output device**?
questions.ex: Headphones allow users to hear audio output from the computer privately.

questions.q: What is the primary difference between a 'soft copy' and a 'hard copy' output?
options: Soft copy is digital, hard copy is physical.
Soft copy is more expensive, hard copy is cheaper.
Soft copy is permanent, hard copy is temporary.
questions.ex: Soft copy is electronic (e.g., on a screen), while hard copy is tangible (e.g., printed on paper).

questions.q: A KVM switch is a device that allows a user to control multiple computers with a single set of:
questions.ex: KVM stands for Keyboard, Video, Mouse, allowing one set of these peripherals to control multiple computers.

questions.q: Which input device uses a grid of sensors to detect the position of a finger or stylus?
questions.ex: Touchpads are commonly found on laptops and use touch to control the cursor.

questions.q: What is the maximum resolution of a display typically measured in?
questions.ex: Resolution is expressed as the number of horizontal pixels by the number of vertical pixels (e.g., 1920x1080 pixels).

questions.q: Which type of printer is best suited for printing receipts or labels quickly and quietly?
questions.ex: Thermal printers use heat to produce an image, often found in point-of-sale systems.

questions.q: Voice recognition software works in conjunction with which input device?
questions.ex: Microphones capture spoken words, which are then processed by voice recognition software.

questions.q: What is the primary role of an Operating System (OS)?
options: To run specific applications like Word Processors
To manage computer hardware and software resources
To protect the computer from viruses
questions.ex: The OS acts as an intermediary between the user and the computer hardware.

questions.q: Which function of an OS involves allocating CPU time to different processes?
questions.ex: Process management handles the creation, scheduling, and termination of processes.

questions.q: The OS function that deals with allocating and deallocating memory space for programs is called:
questions.ex: Memory management ensures efficient use of the computer's main memory.

questions.q: What is the purpose of the 'file system' in an operating system?
options: To organize and store files and folders on storage devices
To display graphics on the screen
questions.ex: The file system provides a logical structure for storing and retrieving data.

questions.q: Which OS function handles requests from applications for hardware resources (like printer or scanner)?
questions.ex: Device management controls and coordinates the operation of hardware devices.

questions.q: The user interface (UI) provided by an operating system can be classified into:
options: Graphical User Interface (GUI) and Command Line Interface (CLI)
questions.ex: GUI uses visual elements, while CLI uses text commands.

questions.q: What is 'multitasking' in an operating system?
options: Running only one program at a time
Allowing a single CPU to appear to run multiple programs simultaneously
Having multiple users on the same computer
questions.ex: Multitasking is the ability of an OS to execute multiple tasks (programs) concurrently over a period of time.

questions.q: Which of the following is NOT a core function of an operating system?
questions.ex: Application software development is done by programmers using development tools, not a core function of the OS itself.

questions.q: The OS function that ensures system stability and protects different programs from interfering with each other is part of:
questions.ex: These aspects contribute to the overall stability and integrity of the system.

questions.q: What does a 'kernel' refer to in an operating system?
options: The core component that manages system resources and facilitates interaction between hardware and software
questions.ex: The kernel is the central part of an OS, responsible for managing basic system services.

questions.q: What is the purpose of 'bootstrapping' in an operating system?
options: To shut down the computer safely
To load the operating system into memory when the computer starts
questions.ex: Bootstrapping is the process by which a computer starts up and loads its operating system.

questions.q: Which OS function is responsible for ensuring that different processes do not corrupt each other's data?
questions.ex: Memory protection mechanisms prevent one process from accessing memory allocated to another.

questions.q: What is the primary role of the 'shell' in a command-line interface (CLI) OS?
options: To interpret and execute user commands
questions.ex: The shell is the command-line interpreter that takes user input and executes corresponding system commands.

questions.q: When an OS performs 'paging' and 'swapping', it is performing part of its:
questions.ex: Paging and swapping are techniques used in virtual memory management to move data between RAM and secondary storage.

questions.q: What is a 'device driver'?
options: A hardware component of a device
A software program that allows the OS to communicate with a specific hardware device
A utility for cleaning hard drives
questions.ex: Device drivers are crucial for the OS to interact correctly with peripherals.

questions.q: Which OS function typically involves creating, deleting, copying, and renaming files and directories?
questions.ex: These are common operations within the file system managed by the OS.

questions.q: The ability of an OS to handle multiple users simultaneously is called:
questions.ex: A multi-user OS allows several users to access the same system resources at the same time.

questions.q: What is the purpose of the 'scheduler' in an operating system?
options: To determine which processes run when and for how long
questions.ex: The scheduler is a component of the OS that selects which processes should be moved from the ready queue to the running state.

questions.q: Which OS function protects system resources from unauthorized access?
questions.ex: Security management includes authentication, authorization, and protection against malicious activities.

questions.q: When an application requests a resource from the OS, this is often handled through:
questions.ex: System calls provide an interface between a process and the operating system services.

questions.q: What is 'deadlock' in the context of operating systems?
options: A situation where a program crashes.
A situation where two or more processes are blocked indefinitely, waiting for each other to release resources.
A method for speeding up CPU processing.
questions.ex: Deadlock is a critical issue in concurrent systems where processes get stuck in a circular waiting pattern.

questions.q: Which OS function is responsible for keeping track of the status of processes and resources?
questions.ex: The OS continuously monitors and accounts for resource usage and process states.

questions.q: The ability of an OS to manage multiple CPUs in a single system is called:
questions.ex: Multiprocessing refers to the use of two or more central processing units (CPUs) within a single computer system.

questions.q: What is the role of an OS in 'error handling'?
options: To detect and respond to errors, both hardware and software.
questions.ex: The OS includes mechanisms to detect, diagnose, and recover from various system errors.

questions.q: Which of the following is an example of an operating system?
questions.ex: Windows is a widely used operating system.

questions.q: What is the main advantage of a Graphical User Interface (GUI) over a Command Line Interface (CLI)?
options: It is faster for experienced users.
It is more intuitive and user-friendly for beginners.
questions.ex: GUIs make computers easier to use for a wider audience due to their visual nature.

questions.q: The concept of 'spooling' (e.g., print spooling) is a feature of which OS function?
questions.ex: Spooling manages the flow of data to slow output devices like printers, allowing the CPU to continue with other tasks.

questions.q: Which component of the OS handles communication between processes?
questions.ex: The kernel provides mechanisms for inter-process communication (IPC).

questions.q: What is the purpose of 'system calls'?
options: To allow applications to directly access hardware.
To provide a structured way for applications to request services from the operating system kernel.
questions.ex: System calls are the interface between user-level programs and the operating system.

questions.q: When a computer is 'booting up', the OS first loads the:
questions.ex: The bootloader is a small program that loads the main part of the OS (kernel) into memory.

subcategories.title: Types of Operating Systems (Batch, Multitasking, Real-Time)

questions.q: Which type of operating system processes jobs in a queue without direct user interaction?
questions.ex: Batch operating systems execute similar jobs as a group (batch) without user interaction during processing.

questions.q: Which operating system allows a single user to run multiple programs concurrently?
questions.ex: Operating systems like Windows or macOS are examples of single-user, multitasking systems.

questions.q: An operating system designed for systems where tasks must be completed within strict time constraints (e.g., industrial control systems) is a:
questions.ex: Real-time operating systems (RTOS) are crucial for applications where timing is critical.

questions.q: Which type of real-time operating system guarantees that critical tasks will be completed within a specified deadline?
questions.ex: Hard RTOS are used in life-critical systems where missing a deadline can have severe consequences.

questions.q: UNIX and Linux are classic examples of which type of operating system, allowing multiple users to access resources simultaneously?
questions.ex: Multi-user operating systems support concurrent access by multiple users.

questions.q: Which type of operating system spreads the computation over multiple physical processors interconnected by a network?
questions.ex: Distributed operating systems manage a collection of independent computers as a single coherent system.

questions.q: An operating system whose primary function is to manage network resources and allow file and printer sharing is typically a:
questions.ex: Network Operating Systems (NOS) are designed to support network clients and manage network resources.

questions.q: MS-DOS is an example of which type of operating system?
questions.ex: MS-DOS allowed only one user to perform one task at a time.

questions.q: Operating systems found in consumer electronics like smart appliances, GPS systems, or medical devices are often classified as:
questions.ex: Embedded operating systems are specialized for specific, often resource-constrained, devices.

questions.q: Which type of OS prioritizes throughput by running jobs in batches, often with minimal CPU idle time?
questions.ex: Batch systems were designed to maximize CPU utilization by processing jobs continuously.

questions.q: Windows 10, macOS, and Ubuntu Desktop are examples of which type of operating system?
questions.ex: These are common operating systems designed for personal computers.

questions.q: Which type of real-time operating system attempts to meet deadlines but does not guarantee them, potentially impacting quality but not causing system failure?
questions.ex: Soft RTOS are used in multimedia systems or scientific applications where missing a deadline might degrade performance but not be catastrophic.

questions.q: What is the primary characteristic of a 'time-sharing' operating system?
options: Allows one user to run multiple tasks.
Allows multiple users to share computer resources simultaneously by giving each a slice of CPU time.
Processes jobs in batches without user interaction.
Dedicated to a single specific task.
questions.ex: Time-sharing systems evolved from batch systems to provide interactive computing to multiple users.

questions.q: Which type of OS is best suited for applications like online transaction processing (OLTP) in banking?
questions.ex: Banking systems require simultaneous access and processing for many users, characteristic of multi-user systems.

questions.q: What distinguishes a 'Network OS' from a 'Distributed OS'?
options: Network OS manages local resources; Distributed OS pools resources to appear as one system.
Network OS is for single users; Distributed OS is for multiple users.
Network OS uses real-time processing; Distributed OS uses batch processing.
questions.ex: A Network OS manages individual computers and their interactions on a network. A Distributed OS creates the illusion of a single, powerful machine from multiple interconnected computers.

questions.q: An ATM machine typically uses which type of operating system?
questions.ex: ATMs run specialized embedded systems tailored for their specific functions.

questions.q: Which of the following is a characteristic of a 'firm real-time' operating system?
options: Failure to meet deadlines leads to system failure.
Missing a deadline is acceptable if it's not frequent.
Missing a deadline results in a loss of value for that specific result, but the system continues.
It is only used for entertainment systems.
questions.ex: Firm RTOS are a middle ground; a missed deadline isn't catastrophic but makes the result useless.

questions.q: Which type of operating system would you expect to find on a supercomputer performing complex simulations?
questions.ex: Supercomputers often utilize highly specialized distributed operating systems or High-Performance Computing (HPC) operating systems to manage their massive parallel processing capabilities.

questions.q: The first generation of computers primarily used which type of operating system?
questions.ex: Early computers relied on batch processing due to lack of interactive capabilities.

questions.q: Which type of operating system would be most suitable for managing a large database server with many concurrent user requests?
questions.ex: Server OS are optimized for handling multiple requests, network services, and high uptime.

questions.q: What is the primary objective of a 'Real-time OS'?
options: To ensure timely and predictable response to events.
To provide a user-friendly graphical interface.
questions.ex: Timeliness and predictability are paramount for RTOS.

questions.q: An operating system that supports only one user and one task at a time is known as:
questions.ex: This describes the most basic type of operating system.

questions.q: Which of the following describes a 'mobile operating system'?
options: An OS designed for smartphones and tablets.
An OS exclusively for server management.
An OS that runs only in batches.
questions.ex: Android and iOS are prime examples of mobile operating systems.

questions.q: What is the main characteristic of a 'client-server' operating system model?
options: All processing happens on the client.
Clients request services from a central server.
It runs only on a single computer.
It does not involve a network.
questions.ex: In this model, clients send requests (e.g., for files, web pages) to servers, which respond with the requested data.

questions.q: Which type of operating system provides a consistent environment for running applications across different hardware platforms?
questions.ex: A portable OS can run on various hardware architectures with minimal or no changes (e.g., Linux).

questions.q: The concept of 'spooling' (e.g., print spooling) was developed to improve the efficiency of which type of OS?
questions.ex: Spooling allowed input/output operations to be done in parallel with CPU operations, improving throughput in batch systems.

questions.q: Which of these is NOT typically a feature of a 'batch operating system'?
questions.ex: Batch systems are non-interactive by nature.

questions.q: What is the primary goal of a 'multitasking operating system'?
options: To allow multiple users to log in simultaneously.
To make the computer appear to perform multiple tasks at the same time.
To execute tasks only in a predefined order.
To minimize the number of programs running.
questions.ex: Multitasking creates the illusion of parallel execution, enhancing user productivity.

questions.q: Which category would Chrome OS (used on Chromebooks) fall under?
questions.ex: Chrome OS is designed for personal computing on laptop-style devices.

questions.q: An OS that is designed to be very small, efficient, and typically runs a single, specific application within a device is an example of a:
questions.ex: This description perfectly matches the characteristics of an embedded operating system.

questions.q: What is a 'process' in the context of an operating system?
questions.ex: A process is an active instance of a program being executed, including its program counter, registers, and stack.

questions.q: Which state does a process enter when it is waiting for some event to occur (e.g., I/O completion)?
questions.ex: A process enters the Waiting (or Blocked) state when it cannot proceed until some external event finishes.

questions.q: What is the primary role of the 'scheduler' in process management?
options: To select which process should be executed by the CPU.
questions.ex: The scheduler is responsible for choosing which process from the ready queue gets the CPU next.

questions.q: The rapid switching of the CPU from one process to another to give the illusion of simultaneous execution is called:
questions.ex: Context switching is the mechanism that allows the OS to save the state of one process and load the state of another.

questions.q: What is a 'thread' in relation to a process?
options: A lightweight process, representing a single sequence of execution within a process.
questions.ex: Threads share the same memory space and resources of their parent process but have their own execution path.

questions.q: Which of the following is NOT part of a Process Control Block (PCB)?
questions.ex: The PCB contains information about the process (state, registers, memory limits, etc.) but not the entire executable code itself.

questions.q: When a process finishes its execution, it enters which state?
questions.ex: The Terminated state signifies that the process has completed its execution and is no longer active.

questions.q: What is 'inter-process communication (IPC)'?
options: Communication between a process and the operating system.
Communication between processes, allowing them to synchronize and exchange data.
questions.ex: IPC mechanisms (like pipes, message queues, shared memory) enable processes to cooperate.

questions.q: Which of the following describes a 'daemon' process?
options: A process that runs only once.
A background process that runs continuously to perform system-wide tasks.
A process that requires direct user interaction.
A process that only handles errors.
questions.ex: Daemons typically start at boot time and run silently in the background, providing services.

questions.q: What is the primary cause of 'deadlock' in concurrent processes?
options: Processes indefinitely waiting for resources held by other waiting processes.
questions.ex: Deadlock occurs when processes are stuck in a circular dependency for resources.

questions.q: The 'dispatcher' module in the OS is responsible for:
options: Saving the state of the CPU for a process.
Loading the state of the CPU for a new process.
Moving control of the CPU to the process selected by the short-term scheduler.
questions.ex: The dispatcher performs the context switch, switching the CPU from one process to another.

questions.q: A 'child process' is created by a 'parent process' using which system call?
questions.ex: The `fork()` system call creates a new process by duplicating the calling process.

questions.q: What is 'process synchronization'?
options: Ensuring all processes run at the same speed.
Coordinating the execution of multiple processes to ensure data consistency and avoid race conditions.
Making sure processes access resources randomly.
questions.ex: Synchronization mechanisms (e.g., semaphores, mutexes) are used to manage access to shared resources.

questions.q: What is a 'race condition' in concurrent programming?
options: When two processes compete for CPU time.
When the outcome of execution depends on the order of specific events, often leading to incorrect results.
When a process finishes too quickly.
questions.ex: Race conditions occur when multiple processes access and modify shared data concurrently, and the final result depends on the order of execution.

questions.q: Which of the following is a common approach to prevent deadlock?
options: Allowing processes to hold resources indefinitely.
questions.ex: Resource ordering is a common deadlock prevention strategy where processes request resources in a predefined order.

questions.q: What is the purpose of the 'wait()' system call?
options: To put a process to sleep indefinitely.
To allow a parent process to wait for its child process to terminate.
To make a process wait for an I/O operation.
To wait for a network connection.
questions.ex: The `wait()` system call is used by a parent process to suspend its own execution until a child process terminates.

questions.q: The state transition from 'Running' to 'Ready' typically occurs due to:
questions.ex: In preemptive scheduling, a running process is moved to the ready state if its allotted time slice expires.

questions.q: Which of the following is a mechanism for inter-process communication?
questions.ex: Pipes allow one-way communication between related processes.

questions.q: What is a 'zombie process'?
options: A process that is still running but unresponsive.
A process that has terminated but its entry still exists in the process table.
A process that is waiting for an I/O operation.
questions.ex: A zombie process has finished execution but its parent has not yet called `wait()` to collect its exit status, leaving its PCB in the table.

questions.q: The 'degree of multiprogramming' refers to:
options: The number of CPU cores in a system.
The number of processes loaded into memory at any given time.
The number of users logged into the system.
questions.ex: A higher degree of multiprogramming means more processes are residing in RAM, ready to execute.

questions.q: What is a 'mutex' (mutual exclusion) used for?
options: To ensure that only one process can access a shared resource at a time.
questions.ex: Mutexes are synchronization primitives that provide exclusive access to a resource.

questions.q: A 'semaphore' is a synchronization tool used to:
options: Control access to shared resources to prevent race conditions.
questions.ex: Semaphores are integer variables used for signaling between processes and controlling access to critical sections.

questions.q: What is the 'critical section problem'?
options: A problem related to concurrent access to shared data.
A problem with slow I/O devices.
questions.ex: The critical section problem deals with ensuring that only one process is executing its critical section (where shared data is accessed) at any given time.

questions.q: Which process state indicates that a process is ready to execute but waiting for the CPU?
questions.ex: Processes in the Ready state are prepared to run as soon as the CPU becomes available.

questions.q: What happens during a 'fork-exec' sequence?
options: A process executes another process within its own memory space.
A process duplicates itself, and then the child process replaces its memory space with a new program.
A process sends a message to another process.
A process creates a new thread.
questions.ex: This is a common pattern in Unix-like systems: `fork` creates a copy, then `exec` loads a new program into the child's memory.

questions.q: Which level of scheduling determines which processes are admitted to the system for processing?
questions.ex: The long-term scheduler controls the degree of multiprogramming.

questions.q: What is the primary benefit of using threads over separate processes?
options: Reduced context switching overhead and easier resource sharing.
questions.ex: Threads are more lightweight, leading to faster context switching and inherent sharing of process resources.

questions.q: If a process requests a resource that is currently unavailable, it will typically transition to which state?
questions.ex: The process will wait until the resource becomes available.

questions.q: What is the 'orphan process' problem?
options: A process that loses its parent process.
A process that cannot communicate with other processes.
A process that consumes too many resources.
questions.ex: An orphan process is a computer process whose parent process has terminated, though it is still running itself.

questions.q: The state transition from 'Waiting' to 'Ready' occurs when:
options: The process requests an I/O operation.
The event the process was waiting for occurs.
The process is preempted by the scheduler.
questions.ex: Once the awaited event (e.g., I/O completion) takes place, the process becomes eligible to run again.

questions.q: What is the primary goal of memory management in an operating system?
options: To store all files on the hard drive.
To allocate and deallocate memory space efficiently and protect processes from each other.
To speed up CPU clock cycles.
questions.ex: Memory management ensures optimal use of RAM and prevents conflicts between processes.

questions.q: Which memory management technique divides a program into fixed-size blocks called 'pages' and memory into fixed-size blocks called 'frames'?
questions.ex: Paging is a non-contiguous memory allocation scheme that eliminates external fragmentation.

questions.q: What is 'virtual memory'?
options: A technique that uses hard disk space to extend physical RAM capacity.
Memory directly accessible by the CPU.
Memory that is only used by the operating system.
questions.ex: Virtual memory allows programs to address more memory than is physically available by using disk storage as an extension.

questions.q: Which of the following is a problem associated with 'contiguous memory allocation'?
questions.ex: External fragmentation occurs when there is enough total free space, but it is divided into small, non-contiguous blocks.

questions.q: What is 'internal fragmentation'?
options: Unused memory within an allocated block.
Memory used by the operating system.
questions.ex: Internal fragmentation happens when memory is allocated in fixed-size blocks, and a process uses only part of a block, leaving the rest unused within the block.

questions.q: The process of moving a complete process from main memory to secondary storage (and vice-versa) is called:
questions.ex: Swapping allows the OS to bring processes in and out of memory as needed, increasing the degree of multiprogramming.

questions.q: Which component translates virtual addresses into physical addresses?
questions.ex: The MMU is a hardware component crucial for virtual memory implementation.

questions.q: In paging, what is a 'page fault'?
options: An attempt to access a page that is not currently in physical memory.
questions.ex: A page fault triggers the OS to load the required page from secondary storage into a free memory frame.

questions.q: What is 'thrashing' in memory management?
options: A situation where the system spends most of its time swapping pages in and out of memory.
A rapid increase in disk storage.
questions.ex: Thrashing severely degrades system performance due to high page fault rates and continuous swapping.

questions.q: Which memory allocation strategy allocates the smallest sufficient free memory hole to a process?
questions.ex: Best Fit aims to leave the largest possible contiguous block of free memory available.

questions.q: Which memory allocation strategy allocates the first free memory hole that is large enough?
questions.ex: First Fit is often simple to implement but can lead to many small, unusable free blocks.

questions.q: Which memory allocation strategy allocates the largest free memory hole to a process?
questions.ex: Worst Fit tries to leave a large block for future large requests, but can also lead to more fragmentation.

questions.q: The 'segmentation' memory management technique divides a program into logical units called:
questions.ex: Segments correspond to logical divisions meaningful to the programmer, such as code, data, stack, or functions.

questions.q: What is the purpose of a 'Translation Lookaside Buffer (TLB)'?
options: To speed up the translation of virtual addresses to physical addresses.
questions.ex: The TLB is a small, fast hardware cache that stores recent virtual-to-physical address translations.

questions.q: When using paging, a 'page table' maps:
options: Logical addresses to physical addresses for files.
Process IDs to their memory locations.
Hard drive sectors to RAM addresses.
questions.ex: Each process has its own page table, which the OS uses to manage its memory.

questions.q: What is 'demand paging'?
options: Loading the entire program into memory at once.
Loading pages into memory only when they are needed.
Pre-loading all possible pages before execution.
Only loading the first page of a program.
questions.ex: Demand paging is a technique where the OS only loads pages into physical memory as they are accessed, improving efficiency.

questions.q: Which of the following is an advantage of 'virtual memory'?
options: Eliminates the need for physical RAM.
Allows programs larger than physical memory to run.
questions.ex: Virtual memory enables programs to function even if their total size exceeds the available RAM.

questions.q: What is the primary goal of a 'page replacement algorithm'?
options: To decide which page to load into memory.
To choose which page to swap out of memory when a page fault occurs and no free frames are available.
questions.ex: Algorithms like FIFO, LRU, Optimal determine which page to remove from RAM to make space for a new one.

questions.q: The 'Least Recently Used (LRU)' page replacement algorithm aims to remove the page that:
options: Has been in memory the longest.
Will not be used for the longest period of time in the future.
questions.ex: LRU attempts to approximate the optimal algorithm by assuming past usage predicts future usage.

questions.q: What is 'compaction' in memory management?
options: Shuffling memory contents to gather all free space into one large block.
questions.ex: Compaction is used in contiguous allocation to overcome external fragmentation by moving processes together.

questions.q: Memory protection mechanisms primarily aim to prevent:
options: One process from accessing the memory space of another process.
questions.ex: Memory protection is crucial for system stability and security in multi-programming environments.

questions.q: Which register is typically used to store the base address of a program segment in memory?
questions.ex: Base and Limit registers are used in simple memory protection schemes to define the bounds of a process's memory.

questions.q: What is 'shared memory' in the context of memory management?
options: Memory accessible only by the OS.
Memory that can be concurrently accessed by multiple independent processes for communication.
Memory shared by different CPU cores.
questions.ex: Shared memory is a common and efficient inter-process communication mechanism.

questions.q: What is the purpose of 'memory mapping'?
options: To draw a map of the memory layout.
To associate a file or device with a portion of a process's virtual address space.
questions.ex: Memory mapping allows files to be treated as if they are directly loaded into a program's memory.

questions.q: The concept of 'locality of reference' is important in the design of:
questions.ex: Locality of reference (both temporal and spatial) explains why cache memory and demand paging are effective, as programs tend to access data and instructions that are near recently accessed ones.

questions.q: What is 'memory swapping' primarily used for?
options: To increase the speed of memory access.
To allow more programs to be loaded and run than physically fit in RAM.
questions.ex: Swapping temporarily moves entire processes between main memory and secondary storage.

questions.q: Which of the following is true about 'logical addresses'?
options: They are the actual addresses in physical memory.
They are generated by the CPU and mapped to physical addresses by the MMU.
They are only used in older systems.
They are the same as physical addresses.
questions.ex: Logical addresses are independent of physical memory locations, providing abstraction.

questions.q: What is the main goal of 'fragmentation' in memory?
questions.ex: Fragmentation, whether internal or external, results in wasted or unusable memory space.

questions.q: In a paged memory system, what is the 'frame table' used for?
options: To keep track of which physical memory frames are free or occupied.
questions.ex: The frame table provides a global view of physical memory allocation.

questions.q: What is the consequence of severe 'thrashing'?
options: Very low CPU utilization and significant performance degradation.
questions.ex: Thrashing implies the system is spending too much time moving data between RAM and disk, achieving little useful work.

questions.q: What is the primary purpose of a file system?
options: To organize, store, and retrieve data on storage devices.
questions.ex: The file system provides a structured way to manage information on persistent storage.

questions.q: Which of the following is a fundamental operation supported by a file system?
questions.ex: Creating, deleting, reading, and writing are core file operations.

questions.q: What is a 'directory' (or folder) in a file system?
options: A container that holds files and other directories.
questions.ex: Directories provide a hierarchical structure for organizing files.

questions.q: What is a 'path' in a file system?
options: The physical location of a file on the disk.
A unique string that identifies the location of a file or directory in the file system hierarchy.
questions.ex: A path specifies how to navigate through directories to reach a particular file or directory.

questions.q: Which of the following attributes is typically NOT associated with a file?
questions.ex: CPU type is a hardware attribute, not a file attribute.

questions.q: What is 'file allocation' in a file system?
options: The process of creating new files.
The method by which disk space is allocated to files.
The way files are displayed to the user.
questions.ex: Common allocation methods include contiguous, linked, and indexed allocation.

questions.q: Which file allocation method stores a file in physically adjacent blocks on the disk?
questions.ex: Contiguous allocation offers fast sequential access but suffers from external fragmentation.

questions.q: Which file allocation method uses a table where each entry points to the next block of the file?
questions.ex: Linked allocation is flexible but can be slow for direct access.

questions.q: Which file allocation method uses an 'index block' or 'inode' to store pointers to all the blocks of a file?
questions.ex: Indexed allocation provides both direct and sequential access efficiently, used in systems like Unix/Linux.

questions.q: What is a 'superblock' in some file systems (e.g., ext4, UFS)?
options: A block that contains information about the entire file system (e.g., size, number of inodes, free blocks).
A backup of the file system.
questions.ex: The superblock is critical for the integrity and organization of the file system.

questions.q: What is the primary role of the 'disk controller' in relation to the file system?
options: To translate logical block addresses from the file system to physical sectors on the disk.
questions.ex: The disk controller handles the low-level communication with the physical disk hardware.

questions.q: What does 'mounting' a file system mean?
options: Physically installing a new hard drive.
Making a file system accessible at a specific point in the directory tree.
questions.ex: Mounting integrates a file system into the existing directory structure.

questions.q: What is 'disk partitioning'?
options: Dividing a disk into one or more logical sections.
Cleaning a disk of unwanted files.
Creating a backup of a disk.
questions.ex: Partitioning allows a single physical disk to function as multiple independent logical drives.

questions.q: What is 'defragmentation' of a disk?
options: Removing bad sectors from a disk.
Rearranging fragmented files to occupy contiguous storage locations.
Erasing all data from a disk.
Creating new files on a disk.
questions.ex: Defragmentation improves performance by reducing seek time for fragmented files.

questions.q: Which of the following is NOT a common file access method?
questions.ex: Common methods are sequential, direct (or random), and indexed sequential.

questions.q: What is a 'file descriptor'?
options: A description of a file's content.
An abstract indicator (usually a small integer) used by the operating system to access a file or other I/O resource.
questions.ex: File descriptors are used by programs to refer to open files, network sockets, etc.

questions.q: What is the purpose of 'file permissions' in a file system?
options: To control who can read, write, or execute a file/directory.
To indicate the file's creation date.
questions.ex: File permissions are a crucial aspect of operating system security.

questions.q: Which of these is a common file system for Windows operating systems?
questions.ex: NTFS (New Technology File System) is the default file system for Windows.

questions.q: Which of these is a common file system for Linux operating systems?
questions.ex: ext4 (fourth extended filesystem) is a widely used journaling file system for Linux.

questions.q: What is a 'journaling file system'?
options: A file system that keeps a log of changes to prevent data corruption during crashes.
A file system used for writing journals.
A file system optimized for video editing.
A file system that does not support large files.
questions.ex: Journaling file systems improve data integrity and allow for faster recovery after a system crash.

questions.q: What is the 'root directory' in a hierarchical file system?
options: The starting point of the entire file system hierarchy.
A directory that only contains system files.
questions.ex: The root directory is the top-most directory from which all other directories and files branch out.

questions.q: What is a 'symbolic link' (symlink) or 'soft link'?
options: A pointer to another file or directory.
questions.ex: Symbolic links are special files that refer to other files or directories, acting like shortcuts.

questions.q: Which of the following is true about 'hard links'?
options: They can link to files on different file systems.
They are essentially different names for the same underlying file data.
questions.ex: A hard link is an additional directory entry for a file, pointing to the same inode (data). They can only exist on the same file system.

questions.q: What is 'disk caching' in the context of file systems?
options: Storing files on a network drive.
Using a portion of RAM to store frequently accessed disk blocks.
Creating backups of the entire disk.
questions.ex: Disk caching improves performance by reducing the number of slow disk I/O operations.

questions.q: The 'inode' in Unix-like file systems contains information about:
options: The actual content of the file.
The file name and directory path.
Metadata about a file (permissions, owner, size, timestamps, data block pointers).
The user who last accessed the file.
questions.ex: An inode is a data structure on a Unix-like file system that stores information about a regular file, directory, or other file system object.

questions.q: What is 'bad sector' on a hard drive?
options: A sector that contains malicious software.
A sector that cannot be read or written to due to physical damage.
A sector used for storing temporary files.
A sector that is currently empty.
questions.ex: Bad sectors indicate permanent damage to the disk surface.

questions.q: The 'file control block (FCB)' contains:
options: The actual data of the file.
File-specific information such as permissions, dates, and pointers to disk blocks.
questions.ex: The FCB is a data structure maintained by the operating system for each open file.

questions.q: What is the primary role of 'file system utilities' (e.g., `fsck`, `chkdsk`)?
options: To check and repair file system inconsistencies.
questions.ex: These utilities are essential for maintaining the health and integrity of a file system.

questions.q: The concept of 'current working directory' allows users to:
options: Access files from anywhere on the system.
Refer to files within that directory without specifying the full path.
Only store files in that specific directory.
questions.ex: It simplifies file access by providing a default location for commands.

questions.q: What is 'RAID' in the context of disk management?
options: A type of file system for flash drives.
A technique for combining multiple physical disk drives into one or more logical units for data redundancy and performance improvement.
questions.ex: RAID (Redundant Array of Independent Disks) is used to improve data storage reliability and speed.

questions.q: What is a file system?
options: A method to name and store files on a disk
An operating system feature for printing
questions.ex: A file system organizes and stores data in files and directories on a storage device.

questions.q: Which of the following is a common file system in Windows?
questions.ex: NTFS (New Technology File System) is commonly used in Windows operating systems.

questions.q: In which file system is journaling used?
questions.ex: NTFS supports journaling, which helps recover from system crashes.

questions.q: Which file system is used by macOS?
questions.ex: APFS (Apple File System) is the default file system for macOS.

questions.q: Which file system supports file permissions and encryption?
questions.ex: NTFS supports file-level security, encryption, and permissions.

questions.q: What is the maximum file size supported by FAT32?
questions.ex: FAT32 has a maximum file size limit of 4 GB.

questions.q: Which of the following is a Linux file system?
questions.ex: EXT4 is widely used as the default file system for Linux distributions.

questions.q: Which structure stores metadata about files?
questions.ex: An inode contains metadata such as permissions, timestamps, and file size.

questions.q: What is the root directory?
options: The base of the file system hierarchy
The largest file in the system
A hidden folder in every partition
questions.ex: The root directory is the topmost directory from which all others stem.

questions.q: Which of these is not a valid file system?
questions.ex: TLS is a security protocol, not a file system.

questions.q: What does 'mounting' a file system mean?
options: Connecting the file system to the directory structure
questions.ex: Mounting makes a file system accessible within the system's directory tree.

questions.q: What is a directory in a file system?
options: A file that stores other files
questions.ex: A directory is a container that holds references to other files and directories.

questions.q: Which file system is best for external drives with cross-platform support?
questions.ex: FAT32 is supported by Windows, Linux, and macOS, making it suitable for external drives.

questions.q: Which command is used in Linux to list files?
questions.ex: 'ls' is the command used in Linux to list files in a directory.

questions.q: What is file fragmentation?
questions.ex: Fragmentation happens when a file is split into pieces scattered across the disk.

questions.q: What is the purpose of defragmentation?
questions.ex: Defragmentation reorganizes fragmented data to improve performance.

questions.q: Which system call is used to open a file in C?
questions.ex: 'fopen()' is used to open a file and associate a stream with it.

questions.q: What does the file extension .txt indicate?
questions.ex: .txt files are plain text files that contain readable characters.

questions.q: What does 'read-only' permission mean?
options: The file can only be viewed
questions.ex: Read-only permission allows viewing but not editing or deleting the file.

questions.q: Which is a hierarchical file structure?
questions.ex: Modern file systems use a tree (hierarchical) structure for organizing files.

questions.q: What happens when you delete a file in most OSes?
options: The file is moved to a recycle bin or trash
questions.ex: Deleted files usually go to a temporary bin from which they can be restored.

questions.q: What is metadata in a file system?
options: Data about the file, like size and permissions
questions.ex: Metadata describes attributes of a file, such as its name, size, and timestamps.

questions.q: Which command is used to change file permissions in Unix/Linux?
questions.ex: 'chmod' changes the permission of a file or directory.

questions.q: What is the function of the 'rm' command in Linux?
questions.ex: 'rm' command is used to delete files or directories.

questions.q: What is the inode table used for?
questions.ex: Inode tables contain metadata about files and directories.

questions.q: Which scheduling algorithm executes jobs in the order they arrive?
questions.ex: FCFS processes tasks in the order they are received.

questions.q: What is the drawback of FCFS scheduling?
questions.ex: Convoy effect occurs when short processes wait for a long process to finish.

questions.q: Which scheduling algorithm selects the process with the shortest expected processing time?
questions.ex: SJF reduces the average waiting time for a set of processes.

questions.q: Round Robin scheduling is most suitable for:
questions.ex: Round Robin is ideal for time-sharing systems due to its equal time allocation.

questions.q: Which scheduling algorithm may cause starvation?
questions.ex: SJF can lead to starvation for longer processes.

questions.q: Time quantum in Round Robin should be:
questions.ex: A very small quantum increases context switching; too large mimics FCFS.

questions.q: Which is a preemptive scheduling algorithm?
questions.ex: Round Robin uses time slices, making it preemptive.

questions.q: What is the main goal of CPU scheduling?
questions.ex: CPU scheduling aims to maximize CPU utilization and throughput.

questions.q: In priority scheduling, a lower number means:
questions.ex: Lower numerical values indicate higher priority.

questions.q: A scheduling algorithm that allows interruption is called:
questions.ex: Preemptive algorithms allow tasks to be interrupted.

questions.q: What causes starvation in priority scheduling?
questions.ex: If high-priority tasks keep arriving, low-priority ones may never execute.

questions.q: Aging in priority scheduling is used to:
questions.ex: Aging gradually increases the priority of waiting tasks.

questions.q: Which algorithm is used in most modern operating systems for multitasking?
questions.ex: Multilevel queue scheduling is used for handling different process types.

questions.q: Which is not a non-preemptive scheduling algorithm?
questions.ex: Round Robin is a preemptive scheduling algorithm.

questions.q: Which of the following considers priority and arrival time?
questions.ex: Multilevel queues manage based on priority and arrival timing.

questions.q: Which algorithm is best for minimizing average waiting time?
questions.ex: SJF provides the lowest average waiting time under ideal conditions.

questions.q: Which algorithm works best when process lengths are similar?
questions.ex: Round Robin is more efficient when all processes take similar time.

questions.q: Which algorithm uses multiple queues for different job types?
questions.ex: Multilevel queue scheduling separates jobs by type and priority.

questions.q: The term 'context switch' is associated with:
questions.ex: Context switch involves saving and restoring process state.

questions.q: Which of these algorithms is suitable for real-time systems?
questions.ex: Earliest Deadline First is designed for real-time scheduling.

questions.q: In multilevel feedback queue scheduling:
options: All processes start in the same queue
questions.ex: Processes can move to higher or lower priority queues.

questions.q: Which algorithm favors shorter burst time but allows longer ones to execute eventually?
questions.ex: MLFQ favors short jobs but includes aging to avoid starvation.

questions.q: Which of these is NOT a CPU scheduling criterion?
questions.ex: Disk speed is related to I/O, not CPU scheduling.

questions.q: Turnaround time equals:
questions.ex: Turnaround time is the total time from arrival to completion.

questions.q: In which case does Round Robin perform poorly?
questions.ex: A very short time quantum increases overhead due to context switching.
